Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, \u00a.proposition: This is an action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, as secured by Massachusetts General Laws c. 186, § 14, for the Defendant's failure to address ongoing disturbances caused by other tenants over an extended period of time.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 1, as this is a civil action in which the damages claimed exceed $25.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Somerville District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2, because the events giving rise to this action occurred within this Court's jurisdiction, and the Defendant conducts business in Somerville, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover actual and consequential damages, as well as statutory damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14, which mandates payment of three times actual damages, or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus attorneys’ fees.

See *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.raw_text: See *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 279 (1994)
See *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that persistent and excessive noise caused by one tenant that substantially interferes with another tenant's use and enjoyment of their leased premises can constitute a violation of quiet enjoyment.
See *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
See *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.support_reasoning: The case does address interference with quiet enjoyment, but the interference here is drug activity and crime in common areas, not persistent and excessive noise caused by another tenant. The opinion holds that a landlord may breach quiet enjoyment by failing to take measures to remove unlawful actors, not by recognizing that noise from a tenant can itself constitute a violation. The proposition overstates the case by converting a specific crime/drug-activity holding into a broader, repeated Massachusetts rule about noisy tenants, which this opinion neither discusses nor establishes.
See *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have repeatedly held that persistent and excessive noise caused by one tenant that substantially interferes with another tenant's use and enjoyment of their leased premises can constitute a violation of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.support_reasoning: The case does discuss interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the interference here was repeated flooding and unsanitary physical conditions caused by the landlord’s failure to maintain the premises, not noise caused by another tenant. The court’s quiet enjoyment analysis focuses on sanitary conditions and flooding, and it nowhere mentions noise, let alone holds that persistent excessive noise from a co-tenant can constitute a violation of quiet enjoyment. Thus, while it is quiet enjoyment authority, it does not support the specific noise-based proposition claimed.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929)… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”
